title: A Disagreement About a Complaint
summary: Tulsi Gabbard is a government leader who helps manage intelligence agencies. An attorney says she has not sent a complaint about her actions to Congress for eight months, claiming it needs a legal review. The complaint was made by someone whose identity is secret because of their job. Gabbard's office denies this, saying there is no delay and that the complaint was reviewed and found not credible by an inspector general. They also say the inspector general was not chosen by Gabbard and started work under President Biden. The attorney wants Congress to look into how the complaint was handled. This story involves government rules and whistleblowers who report problems.

keywords.explanation: a formal statement about something wrong or unfair
a lawyer who helps people with legal issues
the group of people who make laws in the United States
a person who checks if rules are followed in government
someone who reports wrongdoing in their workplace

questions.question: What does the attorney say about the complaint?
options: It was sent to Congress quickly
It has been held up for eight months
questions.correct_answer: It has been held up for eight months

questions.question: What does Gabbard's office say about the complaint?
options: They deny there is a delay and say it was not credible
They want to keep it secret
questions.correct_answer: They deny there is a delay and say it was not credible

questions.question: What does the attorney want Congress to do?

background_read: This article is about a disagreement in government. Tulsi Gabbard is the Director of National Intelligence, which means she helps manage spy agencies. Sometimes, people in government can make complaints if they think something is wrong; these people are called whistleblowers. There are rules to protect them and send complaints to Congress. In this case, an attorney says a complaint about Gabbard has been delayed, but her office says it was reviewed and found not true. This shows how government officials and whistleblowers sometimes disagree, and Congress might need to step in to check the facts.
Article_Structure: WHO: Tulsi Gabbard, an attorney, and Gabbard's office
WHAT: A disagreement about a complaint that has not been sent to Congress
WHERE: Washington, D.C., in government offices
WHY: To report on a conflict over handling a whistleblower complaint and government transparency

perspectives.description: The attorney believes the complaint is being unfairly delayed and should be sent to Congress for review.
Gabbard's office denies any delay and says the complaint was properly reviewed and found not credible.
